child.pub-comments: Ethnologue 16 places the language Marriammu in a new Daly subgroup called Marriammu. There are no other languages in this subgroup.
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Lewis, M. Paul (ed.). 2009. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 16 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/home.asp. (15 February, 2011.)

child.pub-comments: Ethnologue 16 places this language in a subgroup called Marriammu. It is listed as the sole member of this group. Ethnologue 16 also notes that it is "similar to Maridjabin (zmj)" (Lewis 2009).
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List. , Lewis, M. Paul (ed.). 2009. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 16 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/home.asp. (15 February, 2011.)

child.pub-comments: In Top End Handbook, Baker claims that Ami (amy), Marranj Warrgat [N13] and Manda (zma) are in a dialectal relationship, and the language comprising Ami, Manda and Marranungu (zmr) is called Marranj by linguists

Berkeley & Canberra: University of California Press. , Baker, Brett. New Top End Handbook (FileMaker database), ASEDA 0626 edn. Canberra: AIATSIS.

child.pub-comments: "Batjamalh is an Australian language, with about twenty fluent speakers most of whom live at Belyuen on the Cox Peninsula, west of Darwin... All speakers contacted in the course of fieldwork were born into the Wadjiginy tribe or reared by Wadjiginy affines. Fluent Batjamalh speakers call their mahl 'language' Batjamalh and reserve Wadjiginy for the name of the tribe whose malh Batjamalh is. A minority of semi-speakers use Wadjiginy to describe tribe and language. Batjamalh and Wadjiginy are the spellings preferred by fluent speakers of Batjamalh" (Ford 1997: 1).
